title: EverWatt Energy Efficiency Certification - For College Engineers
subtitle: Certification for energy efficiency in community colleges and vocational schools
description: Validate your expertise in identifying and implementing energy efficiency measures for community colleges and vocational schools. This certification covers HVAC, lighting, vocational equipment, and commuter-based operations.

questions.question: What is a key characteristic of community colleges that affects energy efficiency?

options.text: Smaller campuses than universities, often commuter-based with variable occupancy

questions.explanation: Community colleges are typically smaller campuses than universities, often commuter-based with variable occupancy patterns. They may have specialized vocational facilities (auto shops, welding, culinary) that create unique energy efficiency opportunities.

questions.question: A community college has a welding program with 10 welding stations. The exhaust system runs continuously. What efficiency opportunity exists?
questions.scenario: A community college welding lab has 10 welding stations. Each station has local exhaust ventilation (1,000 CFM). The exhaust system runs continuously, even when classes are not in session (approximately 20 hours/week of actual use).

options.text: Install scheduling controls to reduce exhaust during non-class hours
No changes - safety requires constant exhaust

questions.explanation: Installing scheduling controls to reduce exhaust during non-class hours can reduce ventilation energy by 50-70% (from 168 hours/week to 20 hours/week). This maintains safety during class hours while eliminating waste during unoccupied periods. This is typically the highest-impact measure for vocational facilities.

questions.question: What is the typical energy split for community colleges?
questions.explanation: Community colleges typically have: HVAC: 40-55%, Lighting: 20-30%, Plug loads: 10-20%, Vocational equipment: 5-15% (if applicable), Other: 5-10%. The exact split depends on programs offered and building types.

questions.question: A community college has evening and weekend programs. What HVAC scheduling consideration is important?

options.text: HVAC should run 24/7 regardless of schedule
HVAC scheduling must account for variable class schedules including evenings and weekends

questions.explanation: Community colleges often have variable schedules including evenings and weekends. HVAC scheduling controls must account for these variable occupancy patterns to maximize savings while maintaining comfort. Advanced scheduling systems can handle complex schedules.

questions.question: What is the typical priority order for energy efficiency measures in community colleges?

options.text: HVAC Systems, Lighting, Vocational Equipment, Building Envelope
Lighting, HVAC, Building Envelope, Vocational Equipment
Building Envelope, HVAC, Lighting, Vocational Equipment
Vocational Equipment, Lighting, HVAC, Building Envelope

questions.explanation: HVAC systems are typically the highest priority (Very High) due to their large energy share (40-55%). Lighting is High priority. Vocational equipment is Medium-High if applicable. Building Envelope is Medium-High.
